ORAL ANSWERS TO QUESTIONS

CHIEF MINISTER'S VISIT TO
KUALA LUMPUR
(Statement)


    1. Mr John Ede asked the Chief Minister whether he will make a statement on the results of his recent visit to Kuala Lumpur; and, in particular, whether at that visit he made approaches with the view to the improvement of trade relations between Singapore and the Federation.

    The Chief Minister (Mr Lim Yew Hock): Mr Speaker, Sir, at a joint conference of Ministers held in Kuala Lumpur on 3rd May, 1957, a number of subjects of mutual interest to Singapore and the Federation were discussed. The effects of Federation duty on Singapore manufactures received the attention of this joint conference. The Federation Government has since presented to its Legislative Council on Tuesday, 7th May, a White Paper on its protective tariff policy. Singapore made representations to the effect that any form of tariff protection might have adverse economic consequences for both territories. The need for close consultation between the two territories was stressed to ensure that the interests of both territories would be consulted.

    Mr John Ede: Mr Speaker, Sir, will the Chief Minister state whether specific industries were discussed and whether he could hold out hope of employment in the soap industry?

    The Chief Minister: Sir, in view of the delicate nature of the question, we have discussed this in the joint conference in Kuala Lumpur. We tried all we could to persuade them to accept our representations, but in the light of the White Paper which the Federation Government presented on 7th May, we were told that a committee would be formed by the Federation Government to which further representations could be made by this Government.

    Mr John Ede: Mr Speaker, Sir, will the Chief Minister state what further efforts

Column: 1923

he is making or proposes to make to improve trade relations?

    Mr Speaker: That is a different question.

INCREASE IN UNEMPLOYMENT AND STEPS TO REDUCE IT


    2. Mr John Ede asked the Minister for Labour and Welfare what is the estimated increase in the number of unemployed persons in Singapore since April 1955, and what steps are being taken to reduce unemployment.

    Mr Lim Yew Hock: Mr Speaker, Sir, in answer to a similar question in this House in February 1956, I explained that accurate figures for the numbers of unemployed persons in Singapore are not available. For this reason I cannot state the number of unemployed persons in April 1955 any more than I can state the increase or decrease in the number since that date. As recently as last January I informed this House that a study of the various factors which affect employment in Singapore did not suggest that there had been any appreciable change in the unemployment situation during the year 1956. I believe that that still substantially represents the position today. However, I must inform the House that recent reports do seem to indicate a decline in employment in certain industries. For example, there has been a reduction of 10 per cent to 15 per cent in the numbers of workmen employed in the saw-milling and rubber packing factories. Employment in biscuit factories has declined by about 25 per cent. These changes appear to have been due to Federation of Malaya duties and smaller quantities of low-grade rubber imports.

    The retrenchment of about 400 industrial workers at the Naval Base has been well publicised.

    Information collected during the Labour Department's census of manual workers in employment at the end of March has not yet been fully compiled, so that I am unable to state whether there have been increases in other industries to compensate for the decrease I have mentioned. Members will appreciate that in a competitive trading centre like Singapore, there are inevitable

Column: 1924

ups and downs in particular industries. It may be that when the census is complete, it will show a contraction in the employment of manual workers over the last six months; but I am satisfied that the net change will not give rise to undue alarm.

    Employment exchanges' records show counts of persons actively seeking employment assistance at various times as follows: 




April 1955 - 7,031.

April 1956 - 8,122.

April 1957 - 8,074.


    I am bound to point out that the figure for March 1957 was 8,858. Last month there was a sharp fall which will probably only be temporary, as a result of recruitment for census duties.

    To sum up, there has probably been an increase in the number of unemployed persons in Singapore since April 1955, both as a result of school leavers coming on to the employment market and a recent fall in the volume of employment. I estimate that the total is of the order of one per cent of the total number of persons in employment.

    The Government's aim is to pursue a policy of full employment. Public works are maintained at as high a level as resources of the building construction industry allow. These works not merely provide temporary employment for those engaged in actual construction, but permanent employment for those who maintain and operate the schools, hospitals and public buildings which are erected. Government is anxious to create the necessary conditions under which existing industries will expand and new industries can be attracted to Singapore. The Industrial Promotion Board has been set up to assist in this process.

    Mr John Ede: With reference to the steps being taken to reduce unemployment, will the Minister state whether those longest on the unemployment register are given the first chance to train as census workers?

    Mr Lim Yew Hock: Sir, I am not able to reply to this question without notice. I did not know this question

Column: 1925

was coming up. As far as the census work is concerned, it is left to the Registrar to take on people with qualifications. According to the system we employ in the Labour Department, those longest on the list are always given the first choice, but we do not direct any prospective employer as to how he should choose.

Column: 1925

RECOGNITION OF RIGHT TO STRIKE -
ACTION AGAINST
TEMPORARY CLERKS ON STRIKE
(Disparity in treatment)


    3. Mr Lee Choon Eng asked the Chief Secretary-

    (a) whether the Government recognises the fundamental right of a Trade Union to go on strike;

    (b) to state the reasons why action was taken against those temporary clerks who went on strike;

    (c) to state the reasons for the disparity in the treatment of temporary clerks, who were under notice of termination of service, as between those who went on strike and those who did not go on strike.

    Mr S. T. Stewart: Mr Speaker, Sir, with regard to (a) the answer is Yes.

    With regard to (b), there was no official strike of the temporary clerks. What happened was that on the 29th of April two temporary clerks, whose services were to be terminated along with others the following day, absented themselves without permission from their offices and picketed the Government offices, Empress Place. It is understood that they were joined there by four other clerks all of whom had obtained leave of absence. Their action did not have the support of the only union which is recognised as representing the clerical classes, and they did this at a time when the union representatives were negotiating for an extension of the notices terminating their service. The two clerks who had absented themselves did not

Column: 1926

turn up at their office on the 30th. There was therefore no question of extending their notices.

    With regard to (c), Sir, as I have already stated, there was no official strike. To the extent that those who stayed away without leave did not have their notices extended, there was disparity of treatment, but I have already indicated the reason for this in my previous answer. Those who continued to serve up to the 30th of April were allowed to stay on for another month pending the result of the review of the case of temporary clerks by the Public Service Commission. There was, however, no difference in treatment in the matter of the review by the Public Service Commission. Those who absented themselves were not excluded from the review and the Government had made it clear to the union and in a public statement that if, on review, any of them were recommended for absorption, they would be reinstated in the service.

    Mr Lee Choon Eng: Mr Speaker, Sir, can the Chief Secretary tell us what action was taken against those four clerks who had permission to be absent?

    Mr Stewart: Mr Speaker, Sir, with regard to those four clerks, as they had leave of absence, they returned to their offices and no action was taken against them.

Column: 1926

TEMPORARY CLERKS -
RECONSIDERATION OF DISMISSAL


    4. Mr Lee Choon Eng asked the Chief Secretary if the Government will reconsider the case of the dismissed temporary clerks along with those whose services have been extended for one month, after a review and report on the case of temporary clerks by the Public Service Commission.

    Mr Stewart: Mr Speaker, Sir, the up-to-date position is that the Public Service Commission has completed the review and they see no reason to vary their original decision. This means that those temporary clerks not selected will not be absorbed permanently into the General Clerical Service or the General

Column: 1927

Clerical Assistant Service. The Government has, however, found alternative employment in junior jobs for a number of these temporary clerks and will continue in its efforts to find suitable jobs for as many of the others as possible. It must, however, be appreciated that Government's capacity to do this is of necessity very limited.

Column: 1927

SINGAPORE INFANTRY BATTALION
(Recruitment and training)


    5. Mr John Ede asked the Chief Secretary whether he will make a statement on the recruitment and training of the new Singapore Infantry Battalion, and when he expects the Battalion to be fully operational.

    Mr Stewart: Mr Speaker, Sir, the strength of the Singapore Infantry Battalion as at the 20th of May, 1957, was 237. Recruiting is temporarily suspended until 1st August this year because training capacity is full and there are still nearly a thousand applicants who have passed the initial recruiting test and who have not yet been called for medical and personnel selection tests. The next squad will be attested in June from this backlog of one thousand applicants and will leave the temporary barracks at Ulu Pandan for the Malayan Basic Training Centre at Nee Soon in July.

    Three officer cadets are in training at the Federation Military College and two more have recently been earmarked by the Selection Board for training at the Officer Cadet School at Portsea in Australia. All these cadets are due to be commissioned as Second Lieutenants towards the end of 1958.

    There are four squads under training at the Malayan Basic Training Centre, Nee Soon, and all are doing well. The senior squad has begun range training and its standard is promising. The first squad is due to pass out from the Malayan Basic Training Centre on the 6th of July. The next two squads are due to pass out together on 27th July.

    The target date to complete recruit training for the Battalion is August 1958, and it is hoped that the Battalion will be fully operational, by which I take

Column: 1928

it to mean "up to battalion strength and fully and appropriately equipped and trained for its role", by the end of 1958.

SPLIT OF PAN-MALAYAN DEPARTMENTS
(Government Policy)


    7. Mr John Ede asked the Financial Secretary whether in view of the indication given by the Chief Minister, Federation of Malaya, that pan-Malayan departments such as income tax would be split when the Federation attains independence, and the statement made by

Column: 1929

the Chief Minister, Federation of Malaya, that a sub-committee is drafting a separate income tax law for the Federation, he will state the policy of the Government in this matter.

    Mr Oon Khye Kiang: Mr Speaker, Sir, the Government's policy on the administration of income tax is still as stated by my predecessor in his Budget speech on the 7th of November, 1956, and reported in column 607 of the Official Report.

    The Federation Government has made known to this Government her intention of dissolving the present pan-Malayan administration of income tax. This Government has asked her for a discussion so that the various aspects of this matter will be fully considered before a final decision is taken. It is the intention of this Government to bring to her attention the manifold advantages and benefits to the two territories of the present system and the immense unfortunate consequences that would follow a dissolution. It is hoped thereby to persuade her to continue with the present practice.

Column: 1929

ELECTIONS TO CITY COUNCIL
AND DISTRICT COUNCILS
(Date)


    8. Mr John Ede asked the Minister for Local Government, Lands and Housing on what date it is proposed to hold fresh elections to the City Council; and whether elections to the new District Councils will be held on the same date.

    Inche Abdul Hamid Bin Haji Jumat: Mr Speaker, Sir, Government's intention is to hold the City Council elections in December this year. Elections to the District Councils will not take place simultaneously but will be held about March 1958.

    Mr John Ede: Mr Speaker, Sir, will the Minister state the reason why the District Council elections will not take place simultaneously with those of the City Council?

    Inche Abdul Hamid: Mr Speaker, Sir, it is not possible to hold both City

Column: 1930

and District Council elections simultaneously, as more time is required to prepare a further 5,000 pages of the register over and above the City Council register.

    Mr John Ede: Mr Speaker, Sir, is the Minister not aware that the Government has already had plenty of time in which to prepare the register, due to the fact that the White Paper on Local Government was issued many months ago?

    Inche Abdul Hamid: Mr Speaker, Sir, I should like to draw the attention of the Member for Tanglin to the fact that a great deal depends upon how soon the Select Committee on the Local Government Bill will be able to get through its work.

Column: 1930

SCHOOL BUILDINGS IN RURAL AREAS
(Steps to reduce costs)


    9. Mr John Ede asked the Minister for Education what steps have been taken to reduce the cost of new school buildings in the rural areas; and whether he proposes to erect such buildings with materials similar to those used for the Singapore Infantry Battalion buildings at Ulu Pandan.

    Mr Chew Swee Kee: Mr Speaker, Sir, through the combined efforts of the Public Works Department and the Advisory Panel on School Buildings, the standard of construction, finishings and fittings in our new schools has been reduced to a minimum. A considerable saving was made last year by the adoption of a completely new design of three-storeyed schools. Technical advice has also been obtained from the Public Works Department on using cheaper materials for school buildings, such as timber, but saving on first costs would be more than offset by the cost of additional land, for construction would be reduced to two-storeys, and increase in maintenance costs. The need for economy in the use of land and avoiding increasing annually recurrent maintenance cost must therefore outweigh the use of cheaper materials. It is not proposed to build schools using materials similar to those used for the Singapore Infantry Battalion buildings at Ulu Pandan.

Column: 1931

INFLUENZA EPIDEMIC
(Statement)


    10. Mr John Ede asked the Minister for Health whether he will make a statement on the causes of the recent influenza epidemic.

    Mr A. J. Braga: Mr Speaker, Sir, I propose to make a full statement on the influenza epidemic to this House before the business of the day. The statement no doubt will answer many points that may be in the mind of the Member for Tanglin. But to answer this particular question briefly, the cause of influenza is generally by a virus known as Type A or Type B, it was originally thought that the cause of the present epidemic was by Type A, but recent indications are that it might possibly be a new virus previously unknown to medical science. The virus has been sent to the United States, the United Kingdom and Melbourne for identification and further study. The origin of the epidemic is unknown. It is most likely that it originated in Japan where it prevailed extensively, generally in a mild form, but it appears to have invaded Taiwan, the Philippines, Hongkong and the Federation of Malaya, and I believe that it has already now appeared in Australia.

Column: 1931

PROGRESS IN BUILDING FIRST DISTRICT HOSPITAL


    11. Mr John Ede asked the Minister for Health what progress has been made in the construction of the first District Hospital.

    Mr Braga: Mr Speaker, Sir, the site of the District Hospital on East Coast Road has been surveyed, the lay-out site plan approved, and a Gazette notification for the acquisition of the site and access roads will appear or should appear next week. Detailed drawings are in the course of preparation. These, I am told, are due to take at least a year to complete. The ground work, however, is expected to commence in three or four months' time.

    Mr John Ede: Mr Speaker, Sir, is the Minister aware that there is considerable dissatisfaction over the great delay

Column: 1932

in the building of the District Hospital, now extended over two years?

    Mr Braga: Any delay, Mr Speaker, Sir, is outside my own jurisdiction.

    Mr John Ede: Mr Speaker, Sir, does the Minister not regard himself as responsible in any way for the building of the District Hospital?

Column: 1932

MINISTER FOR HEALTH'S VISIT TO JAPAN
(Benefit to Singapore)


    12. Mr John Ede asked the Minister for Health what benefits have accrued to Singapore from his recent visit to medical institutions in Japan.

    Mr Braga: Mr Speaker, Sir, the visits to medical institutions, in particular, the new hospitals, the teaching hospitals, and polyclinics have enabled us to study economical methods and their medical application in a progressive eastern country and the achievements they have been able to report. These observations are now under study and there is reason to believe that both improvements and reduction in costs can be brought about in this colony by using some of the practical and money-saving devices now being used in Japan.

    Mr John Ede: Mr Speaker, Sir, is the Minister aware that the report he has made could equally well have been made by officials in his Ministry?

    Mr Braga: Mr Speaker, Sir, that would be true had the invitation of the Japanese Government been one limited only to attend medical conferences or a conference of medical planners, or purely of professional personnel. The invitation extended to me, as I understood it and as it turned out to be, was not one only to inspect medical institutions and teaching hospitals, but also a goodwill mission. My conversations with the Prime Minister and with men of the top rank, both officially and unofficially, and the exchange of views are in my opinion most useful and contribute to the better understanding of our two Asian countries.

    Inche Ahmad Bin Ibrahim: Would the benefits which the Minister expects

Column: 1933

to accrue from his Japanese trip in terms of dollars and cents be more than the total cost to Government of his mission?

    Mr R. Jumabhoy: What was the cost to the public revenue of his trip, Sir?

    Mr Braga: Mr Speaker, Sir, I must have notice of this question.

Column: 1933

NEW BUS ROUTES
(Applications received and number approved)


    13. Mr John Ede asked the Minister for Communications and Works how many applications for new bus routes have been received by the Omnibus Licensing Authority since the setting up of that body, and how many of such applications have been approved.

    Mr Chew Swee Kee (for the Minister for Communications and Works): Mr Speaker, Sir, the number of applications for new bus routes received by the Omnibus Services Licensing Authority since the setting up of that body on 16th April is 13. Two such applications have been approved and one has been referred back to the sub-committee of the Authority for reconsideration.

    Mr John Ede: Mr Speaker, Sir, will the Minister state the reasons why the Omnibus Licensing Authority is being so obstructive in the matter of allowing new bus routes?

    Mr Chew Swee Kee: Sir, I wish to draw the hon. Member's attention to the recommendation in paragraph 246 on pages 56 and 57 of the Report of the Commission of Inquiry into the Public Passenger Transport System of Singapore, commonly known as the Hawkins' Report. It says in paragraph 246:

    "It does not appear to us that textual amendments to the legislation setting up these temporary arrangements need be extensive, but we consider they should include a provision that the new licensing authority would work under any directions of a general character given by the Minister for Communications and Works, and that one such direction should require the licensing authority not to undertake a reorganisation of existing routes pending the establishment of the new body, whether public authority or company, and not to authorize or approve new or extended

Column: 1934

routes except any which are necessary to give transport services where they are not already provided (with whatever minor overlapping may be unavoidable.)"

    It is based on this recommendation in the Report that the Minister directs the Authority that it should regard its functions as being transitional pending the unification of all the omnibus service undertakings in Singapore. It should accordingly not license any new or extended route except where, in the opinion of the Authority, it is required to give an essential transport service. Sir, the Omnibus Services Licensing Authority has not been obstructive.

    Mr Lim Choon Mong: Mr Speaker, Sir, in the case of new applications which probably have been submitted before the Authority for over half a year, why were not the applicants informed whether their applications were approved or rejected or in the process of being considered?

    Mr Chew Swee Kee: Every applicant, Sir, has been informed of the decision of the Licensing Authority.

    Mr Lee Choon Eng: Arising out of the answer given by the Minister, is it correct for the Government to say then that only two applications have been approved and over twenty have been rejected or disapproved?

    Mr Chew Swee Kee: Yes, two applications have been approved and one, as I have said, has been referred back to the Authority for consideration.

    Mr Lee Choon Eng: What about the twenty and more?

    Mr Chew Swee Kee: The others have been rejected.

    Mr John Ede: Is the Minister aware that large newly developed areas of Singapore require new bus routes and that these are necessary? Will he issue a directive to the Authority to give more assistance to the public?

    Mr Chew Swee Kee: As a result of large developments of housing estates, I have already given instructions to the Authority to consider the needs of the public in relation to transport.

    Mr Lim Choon Mong: Is the Minister aware that an application as far back as September 1956 has not as yet got a reply?

    Mr Chew Swee Kee: As far as I know, no such case has ever happened.

    Mr Lee Choon Eng: Will the Minister state whether any application for deviation of routes within the main route is considered a new route and will the Licensing Authority consider such an application?

    Mr Chew Swee Kee: Sir, it is sub-judice to answer that question because some of the applications are for the deviation of present routes and I would rather not give a definite reply now in order not to prejudice any decision that might be reached by the Authority.

INTRODUCTION OF UNIFIED TRANSPORT SYSTEM
AND REASONS FOR DELAY


    14. Mr John Ede asked the Minister for Communications and Works how soon it is proposed to introduce a unified public transport system for Singapore island, and what are the reasons for the delay in implementing the policy laid down in the Government White Paper (Sessional Paper No. Cmd. 48 of 1956).

    Mr Chew Swee Kee (for the Minister for Communications and Works): Sir, the White Paper to which the hon. Member refers stated that it would not be possible for responsibility for operating any bus services to be assumed by a unified undertaking before the middle of 1958 and that it was aimed to have the whole process completed in 1959. Although no decision has yet been taken as to whether unification should be achieved by means of a public authority or through the formation of a statutory company, the Government does not at present see any reason to modify that time-table. Meanwhile, other preparations are going ahead.

Column: 1936



    Mr John Ede: Mr Speaker, Sir, will the Minister state when the Government proposes to make up its mind on this question in view of its election promises?

    Mr Chew Swee Kee: I have already stated that the Government has already made up its mind. If the hon. Member refers to Sessional Paper No. Cmd. 48 of 1956, paragraph 10 of that Paper states that Government's policy of unifying the passenger transport system should be directed by target dates for the various stages in the implementation of that policy and the time-table is laid down there. Therefore, the Government has never deviated from that policy.

    Mr John Ede: Mr Speaker, Sir, is the Minister aware that his colleague the Minister for Communications and Works (Mr Francis Thomas) gave an assurance at the time of the publication of the White Paper that there would be a debate on this matter? Will he state why this promise has not been kept?

    Mr Chew Swee Kee: I understand that a debate was carried on on the issue of that White Paper. It was already debated in the Assembly.

STEPS TO DEVELOP PRAWN FISHING


    15. Mr John Ede asked the Minister for Commerce and Industry whether he will make a statement on the steps being taken to develop the prawn-fishing industry.

    Mr J. M. Jumabhoy: Mr Speaker, Sir, the first phase of the experiments conducted at the Fisheries Division experimental prawn ponds to determine how to obtain the maximum yield from existing prawn ponds with the lowest expenditure and labour was completed in 1956. The second phase of the experiments began this year. This introduces pig rearing into routine prawn pond operation with the view to increasing the income of the prawn pond operators. The waste products of pig rearing will be used to fertilize the ponds with the object of increasing the yield from the present estimated figure of one-third of

Column: 1937

a ton per acre per annum. My Ministry has been hoping to utilise a further 1,373 acres of swamp land at Ulu Pandan for prawn ponds but since the area is in the Ulu Pandan Forest Reserve, there is a conflict of interest which will need to be sorted out.

    Mr John Ede: Mr Speaker, Sir, is the Minister aware that it has now been discovered that prawns breed in the mangrove areas and will he give due consideration to this important point?

    Mr J. M. Jumabhoy: I certainly will, Sir

GOVERNMENT POLICY ON TOURIST INDUSTRY


    16. Mr John Ede asked the Minister for Commerce and Industry whether he will make a statement on the policy the Government proposes to adopt in respect of the tourist industry.

    Mr J. M. Jumabhoy: Sir, as the hon. Member himself is aware, I am now in consultation with those interests connected with tourism before Government policy on the tourist industry is finalised. I hope therefore to be able to make an announcement on Government policy in the near future.

    Mr John Ede: Mr Speaker, Sir, is the Minister aware that I urged the question of tourist promotion in November 1955 and again in 1956, and that it had the unanimous support of all sections of this House during the Budget debate and will he state the reasons for the delay in deciding on the policy?

    Mr J. M. Jumabhoy: Sir, the hon. Member is aware that an expert had come out from New Zealand to put up recommendations on increasing the tourist trade here. I believe that it was towards the end of last year that his Report was submitted and it does take a bit of time to decide on whether the recommendations should be strictly followed or varied or what other steps should be taken. I am also anxious that Government policy should not be finalised before I have had time to consult with those connected with tourism because they might have suggestions which might be useful.

    The Minister for Health (Mr A. J. Braga): Mr Speaker, Sir, the epidemic of influenza which has visited Singapore has aroused anxiety and I feel it incumbent upon me to make a full statement for the benefit of the House.

A characteristic of this disease is its capacity to attack suddenly, although the actual disease is mild, and to extend very quickly. The extreme conditions of overcrowding, particularly in the town, must certainly have favoured the spread. It must also be realised from the epidemiological point of view that the entire island of Singapore is one composite urban unit with denser aggregations north and south of the Singapore River. In consequence, an island-wide spread was inevitable and indeed the spread to the Federation of Malaya was inevitable. In the view of medical experts, it is likely to prevail in an epidemic form until about the end of this month and from daily reports, there are definite signs of a decline and that it is well on its way out.

    There is no known preventive or cure for the disease. The only course - which was unthinkable - was to close the port of Singapore and all the ports of the Federation of Malaya and the Siamese border against the entry of any craft whatsoever, and impose martial law to keep people in their homes until the disease had spent itself on a worldwide career. There is no specific cure for influenza as there is none for an ordinary common cold. The number of persons affected by the disease in Singapore and attended to by our medical clinics, and mobile and floating dispensaries totalled approximately 25,000.
